questions.question: A small object is placed on the focus on the left side of a convex lens. Where will be the image formed?

options.a: At the centre on the right side of the lens.
options.b: At in ﬁ nity on the left side of the lens.
options.c: At in ﬁ nity on the right side of the lens.
options.d: At the focus on the right side of the lens.

questions.explanation: A t in ﬁ nity on the right side of the lens. Object Position and Image Formation by Convex Lens: When an object is placed between F and 2F, the image is real, inverted, and magni ﬁ ed. At 2F, the image is real, inverted, and the same size as the object. Beyond 2F, the image is real, inverted, and reduced. An object at in ﬁ nity forms an image at the focus (F) of the lens.

questions.question: Name the phenomenon where an opaque object on the path of light becomes very small and where light has a tendency to bend around it and not walk in a straight line.
questions.explanation: Diffr action of light. Examples of Diffraction of light: (i) Bending of light around a sharp edge. (ii) Passing through narrow slits or pinholes. (iii) Observing light through a fog or mist. Angle of refraction - Angle between refracted light and normal to the surface. Angle of incidence - Angle between incident light and normal to the surface.

questions.question: Identify the INCORRECT pair regarding the material media and their refractive index ?
questions.explanation: Benz ene – 2.42. The refractive index of an optical medium is a dimensionless number that gives the indication of the light bending ability of that medium. Absolute refractive index of some material media : Benzene - 1.50, Rock salt - 1.54, Carbon disulphide - 1.63, Dense ﬂint glass - 1.65, Diamond - 2.42, Crown glass - 1.52, Turpentine oil - 1.47, Water - 1.33, Alcohol - 1.36, Fused quartz - 1.46, Air - 1.0003.Q.4. Who proposed that ‘Light is made up of waves propagating perpendicular to the direction of its movement’ ? SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (2nd shift) (a) Kepler (b) Huygens (c) Pauli (d) Newton Sol.4.(b) According to Huygens' theory, light travels as waves, with the wavefronts propagating perpendicular to the direction of motion. In contrast, Newton supported the particle theory of light.

questions.question: Which part of the bifocal lens facilitates near vision?
questions.explanation: Lower par t with conv ex lens. A common type of bi-focal lenses consists of both concave and convex lenses. The upper portion consists of a concave lens. It facilitates distant vision. The lower part is a convex lens. It facilitates near vision.

questions.question: A concave spherical mirror has a radius of curvature of 30 cm. An object was placed 15 cm away from the pole in front of the mirror on the principal axis. Choose the correct option for the position, size and nature of the image formed, respectively.

options.a: Behind the mirror, enlarged, virtual and erect
options.b: At in ﬁ nity, highly enlarged, real and inverted
options.c: Between Focus and Centre, diminished, real and inverted
options.d: At the focus, highly diminished point-sized, real and inverted

questions.explanation: A t In ﬁ nity , highly enlar ged, r eal and inv er ted. We know that, focus of a mirror, f = R/2, where R is the radius of curvature of the mirror. Here in this case, f = - 30/2 = -15 cm. Also, distance of the object from the mirror, u = -15 cm. It means that the object is placed at the focus of the mirror. When an object is positioned at the focus of a concave mirror, the resulting image is formed at inﬁ nity. This image will be signiﬁ cantly enlarged and will have a real and inverted nature.

questions.question: In optics, which term refers to the opening of the diaphragm of a lens that spatially limits the propagation of light ?
questions.explanation: A per tur e. Collimator - A device which narrows a beam of particles or waves. Apostilb - An obsolete unit of luminance. Meniscus - A C-shaped piece of tough, rubbery cartilage that acts as a shock absorber between the shinbone and the thigh bone.

questions.question: White light is an example of :
questions.explanation: P oly chr omatic light - The light consists of a broad range of wavelengths. Example - Mercury Light, Sunlight, Laser-pumped plasma light. Monochromatic light - The light consists of only one speci ﬁ c wavelength. Example - Laser beam, Sodium lamps, Spark lamps.

questions.question: Which telescope was invented by Isaac Newton in the 17th century by using a concave mirror to collect light instead of a simple lens which produces false colors due to the dispersion of light?
questions.explanation: Re ﬂ ecting telescope. Two major types of telescopes : Re ﬂ ecting Telescopes and Refracting Telescopes (used lenses to magnify objects). Infrared telescope : Uses infrared light to detect celestial bodies.

questions.question: The minimum distance of distinct vision for a young adult person with no defect in eyes is :
questions.explanation: 25 cm. For a normal eye, the far point is at in ﬁ nity and the near point of distinct vision is about 25 cm in front of the eye. Hypermetropia (far - sightedness) : When the point goes farther from 25 cm. Lens used : Convex. Myopia (Nearsightedness): Near objects appear clear, but objects farther away look blurry. Lens used : Concave.

questions.question: Which colour of light from VIBGYOR has minimum energy ?
questions.explanation: Red. It has the longest wavelength and least energy of the visible colors of light. Wavelength - The distance between two successive crests or troughs. Violet has the shortest wavelength. Frequency - It refers to the number of waves passing through a point per second. Violet has the highest frequency. The white light consists of 7 colors VIBGYOR (Violet - Indigo - Blue - Green - Yellow - Orange - Red).

questions.question: Why can you not see objects in a dim lit room when you come from a brightly lit room?

options.a: The iris dilates the eye lens to allow less light to enter the eye.
options.b: The iris contracts the pupil to allow less light to enter the eye.
options.c: The vitreous humour dilates the pupil to allow less light to enter the eye.
options.d: The cornea contracts the pupil to allow less light to enter the eye.

questions.explanation: Iris - It gives a distinct color to the eyes. The eyeball is spherical in shape having a diameter of 23 mm. Vitreous humor present in between lens and retina. Retina contains three layers of neural cells (ganglion cells, bipolar cells, photoreceptor cells). Cornea - The front most and transparent covering of the eye. Light enters the human eye through the cornea.

questions.question: What will be the focal length of a convex lens with the power of a +2.5 Diopter?
questions.explanation: 40 cm. Given, Power (P) = + 2.5 diopters. Using the formula, focal length of convex Lens, f = 1/P = 1 / 2.5 = 0.4 meters = 40 centimeters .Focal length of convex lens is always positive and of concave lens is always negative.

questions.question: An image formed by the convex mirror is always _________.
questions.explanation: Vir tual and er ect. Conv ex mirr or (Diverging Mirror) -It has a reﬂ ecting surface that bulges outwards, and away from the centre of curvature. Uses - Rear view mirrors, Street light reﬂ ector, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of position of object – position of image – size of image, is NOT correct for concave mirror ?

options.a: At F - At in ﬁ nity - Highly enlarged
options.b: Between C and F - Beyond C - Enlarged
options.c: Beyond C - Between F and C - Diminished
options.d: At in ﬁ nity - At C - Highly diminished

questions.explanation: A t in ﬁ nity - A t C - Highly diminished. Image formation by Concave Mirror (Object Position - Image Position - Image Nature and Size) : (At In ﬁ nity - At F - Real - Point size); (Beyond Center C - Between C and F (Focus) - Diminished - Real and Inverted); (On Centre - Real, inverted and same size); (Between Centre (C) and Focus (F) - Beyond Centre - Real, inverted and larger); (On Focus - Inﬁ nity - Real, inverted and enlarged); (On Focal length (Between Pole and Focus) - Behind Mirror - Virtual, straight and enlarged).

questions.question: If ‘u’ is the object-distance, ‘v’ is the image-distance and ‘f’ is the focal length of a spherical mirror then which of the following is a correct expression for the mirror formula?
questions.explanation: 1/v + 1/u = 1/f. There are two types of spherical mirrors : Concave mirrors (If the re ﬂ ective surface is on the side curved inwards) and Convex mirrors (if the re ﬂ ective surface is curved outwards). The lens formula is 1/v - 1/u = 1/f.

questions.question: The splitting of white light into its component colours is called ______.
questions.explanation: Dispersion. Refraction - Redirection of a wave as it passes from one medium to another. Reﬂ ection - When a ray of light approaches a smooth polished surface, it bounces back.

questions.question: The re ﬂ ection on a bathroom mirror, the lake and the glare on a pair of glasses are caused by which type of reﬂ ection?
questions.explanation: Specular r e ﬂ ection is deﬁ ned as light re ﬂ ected from a smooth surface at a de ﬁ nite angle like a reﬂ ection on a bathroom mirror. Diffuse re ﬂ ection is produced by rough surfaces that tend toreﬂ ect light in all directions like reading a newspaper.

questions.question: Apart from the red and green wavelengths of sunlight, which other wavelength of sunlight is absorbed by water molecules in the ocean?
questions.explanation: Y ellow. When sunlight hits the ocean, some of the light is re ﬂ ected back directly but most of it penetrates the ocean surface and interacts with the water molecules.

questions.question: Which of the following types of mirrors show a lateral inversion of light?
questions.explanation: Plane mirr or. Lateral inversion is the reversal of a mirror image where the right side of the object appears on the left side behind the mirror. Characteristics of a Plane mirror - Images are Virtual and Erect. Image is formed behind the mirror. The size of the image is equal. The distance of image and mirror is equal to the distance of object and mirror.

questions.question: The color of the clear sky is blue due to the phenomenon of :
questions.explanation: Scattering of light. CV Raman was awarded the Nobel prize in Physics in 1930 for his discovery of Raman effect (Scattering of light). The Tyndall effect is the phenomenon of the scattering of light by colloidal particles.

questions.question: The total number of images formed by two mirrors inclined at 120° symmetrically to each other is ______.
questions.explanation: 2. The number of images formed when two mirrors are placed at an angle theta ( ) to each other is given θ by : n = (360° / ) - 1 θ So, here, we have the mirrors placed at an angle = 120° θ No. of images formed, n = ( 360° /120° ) - 1 = 3 - 1 = 2 So, a total of two images will be formed.

questions.question: Calorimeter is a small container made of a thin sheet of _________ with good thermal conductivity.
questions.explanation: copper . A calorimeter is a device used to measure heat. It consists of a metallic vessel and stirrer, often made of copper or aluminum, which absorb minimal heat while effectively conducting it.

questions.question: The variation between a high air temperature and a low temperature that occurs during the same day is called _______ temperature.
questions.explanation: diurnal. Wet bulb temperature is the lowest temperature to which air can be cooled by the evaporation of water into the air at a constant pressure.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding water remaining colder in an earthen pot (matka) ?

options.a: Water gets evaporated at the surface of the earthen pot.
options.c: Environmental water vapour enters the pot through pores.
options.d: The water oozes out through the pores in an earthen pot.

questions.explanation: Water in earthen pots cools through evaporation from the clay’s tiny pores, which absorbs heat and lowers the temperature, especially in summer. Additionally, the alkaline clay helps balance body acidity, promoting a healthy pH and reducing stomach issues.

questions.question: How much will be 59°F in Celsius ?
questions.explanation: 15°C. To convert 59°F to Celsius, we use the formula: C = × (F − 32) = × (59 − 32)5 95 9 C = × 27 = 15.

questions.question: The transfer of heat through horizontal movement of air is called ____.
questions.explanation: adv ection. Some other mode of heat transfer - Conduction : Heat transfer through direct contact between materials. Convection : A process in which heat is carried from place to place by the bulk movement of a ﬂuid and gases.

questions.question: In which method of cooking is food heated slowly over a source of heat and cooked by high heat and air convection depending on the position of the food in relation to the ﬁr e ?
questions.explanation: Spit - r oasting. Braising - The cooking of meat or vegetables by heating them slowly with oil and moisture in a tightly sealed vessel. Poaching - A moist heat method of cooking by submerging food in some kind of liquid and heating at a low temperature.

questions.question: Who coined the term 'zeroth law of thermodynamics' in 1931, which asserts that two bodies in equilibrium with a third are in equilibrium with each other ?
questions.explanation: Ralph H F owler . Thermodynamics deals with the relations between heat and other forms of energy. James Clerk Maxwell - Theory of electromagnetism. Max Planck - The quantum of action (Planck's constant). Josiah Willard Gibbs - Gibbs energy (Available energy in a system).

questions.question: Triple point can be de ﬁ ned as:

options.a: the condition of temperature under which the gaseous and liquid phases of a substance can exist in equilibrium
options.b: the temperature at which solid is converted into liquid
options.c: the condition of pressure under which the solid and liquid phases of a substance can exist in equilibrium
options.d: the condition of temperature and pressure under which the gaseous, liquid and solid phases of a substance can exist in equilibrium

questions.explanation: The triple point of water is at 273.16 kelvin (0.01 °C or 32.02 °F) and a pressure of 611.7 Pascals.

questions.question: According to_________ law, heatproduced by an electric current is directly proportional to the resistance of the conductor, the square of the current, and the time for which it ﬂows.
questions.explanation: Joule ' s. Joule's law of heating, H = I2Rt, where, H - Heat, I - Current, R - Resistance, t - time. Hooke's law (law of elasticity) - Discovered by the English scientist Robert Hooke in 1660, which states that, for relatively small deformations of an object, the displacement or size of the deformation is directly proportional to the deforming force or load.

questions.question: Tensile or compressive stress can also be termed as _______.
questions.explanation: Longitudinal str ess (axial stress) .Other types of stress : Tangential stress is a type of stress that acts perpendicular to the surface of an object. Hydraulic stress is a type of stress that is caused by the pressure of a ﬂuid. Shearing stress is a type of stress that acts parallel to the surface of an object.

questions.question: In which of the following ways of heat transfer no medium is required ?
questions.explanation: Radiation : Energy that comes from a source and travels through space at the speed of light. It has wave-like properties and can be called “electromagnetic waves”. Conduction : Process by which heat energy is transmitted through collisions between neighbouring atoms or molecules.

questions.question: What is the Steam Point on the Fahrenheit scale ?
questions.explanation: 212°F .Steam point is the temperature at which the maximum vapour pressure of water is equal to one atmosphere. It has a value of 100°C on the Celsius scale.

questions.question: Heat, in ________ is a type of energy transfer from a warmer substance to a colder one.
questions.explanation: Thermodynamics. During energy transfer, the energy moves from the hotter object to the colder object. This means that the hotter object will cool down and the colder object will warm up. The energy transfer will continue until both objects are at the same temperature. Heat is measured in joules (J).

questions.question: _______ expansion makes the Eiffel Tower taller during summers.
questions.explanation: Thermal expansion is a phenomenon due to which the metal expands when heated and contracts when cooled. The Eiffel Tower gets taller by up to 6 inches during the summer.

questions.question: Who discovered a principle that states that the buoyant force on an object is equal to the weight of the ﬂuid displaced by the object ?
questions.explanation: Ar chimedes. Formula, F = ρ × g × V where F is the buoyant force, ρ is the density of the ﬂuid, V is the submerged volume and g is the acceleration due to gravity.

questions.question: In 1851, who founded the science of hydrodynamics with his law of viscosity describing the velocity of a small sphere through a viscous ﬂuid?
questions.explanation: Geor ge Gabriel St ok es. Heinrich Gustav Magnus - Known for Magnus effect, an observable phenomenon that is commonly associated with a spinning object moving through the air or a ﬂuid.

questions.question: Whose law states that total energy per unit mass of ﬂowing ﬂuid, at any point in the subsurface, is the sum of the kinetic, potential, and ﬂuid-pr essure energy and is equal to a constant value?
questions.explanation: Daniel Bernoulli. Pascal's law - The pressure applied to an enclosed ﬂuid will be transmitted without a change in magnitude to every point of the ﬂuid and the walls of the container. Poiseuille's law - It gives the pressure drop in an incompressible and Newtonian ﬂuid in laminar ﬂow ﬂowing through a long cylindrical pipe of a constant cross - section.

questions.question: _______ forces water through a semipermeable membrane and removes contaminants.
questions.explanation: Re v erse Osmosis . Filtration is the process in which solid particles in a liquid or gaseous ﬂuid are removed. Boiling is the process by which a liquid turns into a vapor when it is heated to its boiling point. Distillation is a process involving the conversion of a liquid into vapor that is subsequently condensed back to liquid form.

questions.question: What is the relative density of silver
questions.explanation: 10.8. Relative density is a comparative measure of the density of a substance to the density of a reference substance (Usually water).

questions.question: Four resistors of equal resistance R each are connected in various possible ways both in series and/or parallel to get different combined resistances. Which of the following values of resistance cannot be achieved by using all the four resistors?
questions.explanation: 2 R. Case 1 - All resistances are connected in series. Req= R + R + R + R = 4 R Case 2 - All resistances are connected in parallel. = + + + =1 𝑅𝑒𝑞1 𝑅1 𝑅1 𝑅1 𝑅4 𝑅 = 0.25 R𝑅𝑒𝑞Case 3 - 3 resistances are connected in parallel and one in series. = + + =1 𝑅𝑝1 𝑅1 𝑅1 𝑅3 𝑅 =𝑅𝑝 𝑅 3 = + R = 1.33 R𝑅𝑒𝑞 𝑅 3 Case 4 - 2 resistances are connected in series and 2 in parallel. = +1 𝑅𝑝1 𝑅1 𝑅 = 0.5 R𝑅𝑝 Rs= R + R = 2 R = Rs+ = 2 R + 0.5 R = 2.5 R 𝑅𝑒𝑞𝑅𝑝 The value 2𝑅 cannot be achieved by using all four resistors in any conﬁ guration.

questions.question: An electric iron requires a ________ fuse to prevent short circuiting.
questions.explanation: 5 A. An electric iron requires a fuse rated slightly higher than the operating current to prevent short-circuiting. For example, an iron consuming 1 kW of power at 220 V has an operating current of approximately 4.55 A. Thus, a 5 A fuse is appropriate as it allows normal operation without blowing.

questions.question: In the Right-Hand Thumb Rule, the thumb is directed towards the direction of :
questions.explanation: curr ent. The right-hand thumb rule states that if you hold a current-carrying wire with your right hand, with your thumb pointing in the direction of the electric current, the direction your ﬁngers curl indicates the direction of the magnetic ﬁeld lines. This rule helps visualize the relationship between current and magnetic ﬁelds.

questions.question: If a bar magnet is hung from a string, in which direction does its north pole point?
questions.explanation: Nor th. When a bar magnet is hung freely from a string, its north pole aligns with the Earth's magnetic ﬁeld and points toward the Earth's magnetic north pole. This happens because opposite magnetic poles attract; since the Earth's magnetic north pole is actually a magnetic south pole, it attracts the north pole of the magnet, causing it to point north.

questions.question: A circular coil having ‘n’ turns produces a ﬁeld _______ times large as that produced by a single turn
questions.explanation: n. The magnetic ﬁeld pr oduced by a circular coil depends on the number of turns, the current passing through the coil, and other factors like the radius of the coil and the medium in which the coil is placed. For a given current and coil geometry, the strength of the magnetic ﬁeld at the center of a coil is proportional to the number of turns in the coil.

questions.question: In an electrical circuit, the ammeter reading decreases to ______when the length of the wire is doubled.
questions.explanation: one-half. According to Ohm's law, the resistance 𝑅of a conductor is directly proportional to its length 𝑙and inversely proportional to its area of cross-section 𝐴. Doubling the length increases the resistance, which reduces the current, leading to a halving of the ammeter reading. That is, R ∝ 𝑙and R∝ . We get R ∝ or, R = ρ .

questions.question: Which device is used to measure the current ﬂow using needle deﬂ ection caused by a magnetic ﬁeld force acting upon a current-carrying wire ?
questions.explanation: Galv anometer : An electrical measuring instrument used to detect current ﬂow by measuring the needle deﬂ ection caused by the magnetic ﬁeld acting on a current-carrying wire. The deﬂ ection is proportional to the current.

questions.question: Which of the following is used for determining the value of 1 ampere.
questions.explanation: A = 1C/s. 1 Ampere = 1 Coulomb/second. This equation shows that one ampere is equal to one coulomb of electric charge ﬂowing per second. Ampere (A) is the SI unit of Electric Current.Q.50. Identify the device used to change the resistance in an electric circuit. SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (3rd shift) (a) Ammeter (b) Rheostat (c) Conductor (d) Voltmeter Sol.50.(b) Rheostat. Ammeter is a device used to measure either alternating or direct current. Insulators are those substances through which electricity cannot ﬂow easily.

questions.question: _________ is commonly represented by the Greek letter ρ (rho).
questions.explanation: Electrical r esistivity . The SI unit of resistivity is the ohm-meter (Ω-m). Current is usually denoted by ‘I’; unit - Ampere (A). Electrical conductivity is denoted by the Greek letter sigma (σ); unit - siemens per metre (S/m) or mho.

questions.question: Which of the following is a poor conductor of electricity ?
questions.explanation: Distilled water is a poor conductor of electricity because it lacks dissolved salts and minerals that enhance conductivity. Good conductors of electricity are materials that facilitate the easy ﬂow of electric current, typically containing free-moving electrons. In contrast, poor conductors resist the ﬂow of electric current, making it di ﬃ cult for electricity to pass through them.

questions.question: Which metallic element is called ‘ferromagnetic’ because of its strong attraction ?
questions.explanation: Ir on (Symbol : Fe, Atomic Number : 26) exhibits strong magnetic properties and is strongly attracted to magnets. Ferromagnetism is the ability of materials like iron, cobalt, and nickel to be magnetized and in ﬂ uenced by magnetic ﬁelds.

questions.question: An argon positive ion ﬁr ed towards east gets de ﬂ ected towards south by a magnetic ﬁeld. The direction of magnetic ﬁeld is :
questions.explanation: upwar d. The proton is projected towards east and the direction of magnetic force on the proton is along the south. Using the right hand thumb rule, the direction of the magnetic ﬁeld is vertically upwards. The induced current is found to be the highest when the direction of motion of the coil is at right angles to the magnetic ﬁeld.

questions.question: Using Fleming’s right-hand rule, in which direction will the current ﬂow if the direction of magnetic ﬁeld is towards north and the conductor is moving vertically upward ?
questions.explanation: T owar ds west. If the fore ﬁ nger indicates the direction of the magnetic ﬁeld and the thumb shows the direction of motion of the conductor, then the middle ﬁnger will show the direction of induced current. This simple rule is called Fleming’s right-hand rule.

questions.question: An electric generator and an electric motor work in the principle of:

options.b: Fleming's left and right - hand rule, respectively
options.d: Fleming's right and left - hand rule, respectively

questions.explanation: Fleming' s right and left-hand rule r espectiv ely - A right hand and left hand is stretched so that the thumb, middle ﬁnger , and index ﬁnger form a 90-degree angle with each other. The thumb then represents the direction of motion or force (F), the middle ﬁnger the direction of current (I), and the index ﬁnger the direction of magnetic ﬁeld (B).

questions.question: The neutral point in the magnetic ﬁeld of a horizontally positioned bar magnet is the :

options.a: point where the magnetic ﬁeld changes direction
options.b: point where the magnetic ﬁeld is the weakest
options.c: point where the magnetic ﬁeld is the strongest
options.d: point where the magnetic ﬁeld is zero

questions.explanation: Neutral point : It is a point where the magnetic ﬁeld produced due to a bar magnet is completely balanced by the horizontal component of Earth's magnetic ﬁeld. Magnetic Field - The region around a magnetic material or a moving electric charge within which the force of magnetism acts. Types of magnets : Permanent magnet, temporary magnet and electromagnet.

questions.question: In 1834, who proposed a law that states that the current induced by a change in ﬂow opposes the effect producing the change ?
questions.explanation: Heinrich F riedrich Lenz. Lenz’ s law - An induced electric current ﬂows in a direction such that the current opposes the change that induced it. Lenz’s law is used in electromagnetic brakes and induction cooktops. It is also applied to electric generators, AC generators. Sir Da vid Br ewster - Brewster law is a statement that says that when unpolarized light falls on an interface, the reﬂ ected light is completely polarized if the angle of incidence is a speci ﬁ c angle called the Brewster's angle.

questions.question: Which of the following options is correct for Coulomb's law ?

options.a: Valid for both point and distributed charges
options.d: Valid for neither point charge nor distributed charge

questions.explanation: V alid for only point char ge. Coulomb ’ s Law : The electrical force between two charged objects is directly proportional to the product of the quantity of charge on the objects and inversely proportional to the square of the separation distance between the two objects. F = , where {Q1- quantity𝑘 𝑄1 𝑄2 𝑑2 of charge on object 1 (in Coulombs), Q2- quantity of charge on object 2 (in Coulombs), and d - distance of separation between the two objects (in meters). k - proportionality constant (the Coulomb's law constant)}. Value of k - 8.988 × 109Nm2/C2.

questions.question: Which of the following laws state that “The magnitude of the induced EMF in a circuit is equal to the time rate of change of magnetic ﬂux through the circuit”?
questions.explanation: F ar ada y ' s law . Laplace ' s law - The tension in the walls of a hollow sphere or cylinder is dependent on the pressure of its contents and its radius.

questions.question: Which of the following is the proper number of electrons in 1 A of current ?
questions.explanation: 6.25 × 101 8. Electric Curr ent - The rate of ﬂow of electrons in a conductor. SI Unit - Ampere (A). Conduct ors are de ﬁ ned as the materials or substances that allow electricity to ﬂow through them. Examples - Human body, aqueous solutions of salts and metals like iron and silver.

questions.question: Which of the following has the highest value of resistivity ?
questions.explanation: Nichr ome. Resistivity - It is the measure of the resistance ability of a material to oppose the ﬂow of current. Electrical resistivity is the reciprocal of electrical conductivity. High Resistivity Materials - Ebonite, Tungsten, Carbon. High conductivity materials - Copper, iron, aluminium, and silver.

questions.question: Which of the following elements is highly effective for making a permanent magnet ?
questions.explanation: Steel. P ermanent magnets are made from special alloys (ferromagnetic materials) such as iron, nickel and cobalt, several alloys of rare-earth metals and minerals such as lodestone; Used in headphones, loudspeakers, MRI Scanners, hard disc drives, generators, transducers. Magnetite (Fe 3O4) - An ore of iron that has magnetic properties (ferrimagnetic).

questions.question: If four resistors of 3 Ω, 4Ω, 5Ωand 6Ωar e connected in series, what will be the combined resistance of the four resistors?
questions.explanation: 18 Ω .In series connection of resistors (Here, 3 Ω, 4Ω, 5Ω, 6Ω), Currentthrough each resistor is same. Voltage drop across each resistor is proportional to its resistance. The total resistance is equal to the sum of the individual resistances. Equivalent resistance Rn= R1 + R2+ R3+ R4= 3Ω+ 4Ω+ 5Ω+ 6Ω= 18Ω.

questions.question: When will you ﬁnd the magnetic ﬁeld stronger?

options.c: When the ﬁeld lines are not seen

questions.explanation: Magnetic ﬁelds (Symbol B or H, Unit - Tesla) : William Gilber t discovered that the Earth is a magnet. The strength of magnetic ﬁeld lines depends on how close the magnetic ﬁeld lines are. Some properties related to magnetic ﬁeld lines are: Strongest near the poles (N or S), never crosses each other, always make closed loops.

questions.question: Which of the following materials is a conductor of electricity ?
questions.explanation: Silv er . The material that allows ﬂow of electric current with little or no resistance are called conductors. Examples - Copper, Aluminum, human body. Glass, mica, rubber and ebonite are insulat ors.

questions.question: Which device is used to either break an electric circuit or to complete it?
questions.explanation: Switch - It is a device used to interrupt the ﬂow of electrons in a circuit. Insulat or - A material in which electric current does not ﬂow freely. Examples - Glass, air, wood, plastic and rubber.

questions.question: Identify the correct statement.

options.a: Resistance of a wire depends on the length and density of the wire.
options.b: Speciﬁ c resistance is the same for all conductors.
options.c: Resistance of a wire depends on the length and cross-section of the wire.
options.d: Speci ﬁ c resistance is dependent on the cross-sectional area of the wire.

questions.explanation: The r esistance of a wir e is directly proportional to its length and inversely proportional to its cross -sectional area. Resistance is a measure of the opposition to current ﬂow in an electrical circuit. It is measured in ohm (Ω). F act ors aff ecting r esistance - Material's conductivity, Length, Cross-sectional area and Temperature.

questions.question: A light bulb working on a 18V battery draws a current of 3A. What will be the resistance of the bulb?
questions.explanation: 6 Ω. Voltage = 18 V, Current = 3 A. Since, Voltage (V) = Resistance (R) × Current (I). Resistance = .𝑉𝑜𝑙𝑡𝑎𝑔𝑒 𝐶𝑢𝑟𝑟𝑒𝑛𝑡 Resistance = = 6 Ω.

questions.question: The induced current is the highest when the direction of motion of the coil is:

options.a: not at right angles to the magnetic ﬁeld
options.b: at right angles to the electricity
options.c: at right angles to the electric source
options.d: at right angles to the magnetic ﬁeld

questions.explanation: at right angles t o the magnetic ﬁ eld. The induced current is highest when the direction of motion of the coil is at 90° or perpendicular with respect to the magnetic ﬁeld, as the ﬂux cutting is maximum in this case. While it is minimum when the direction of motion of the coil is at 180° or parallel with respect to the magnetic ﬁeld, as here the ﬂux cutting by the coil will be minimum.

questions.question: If Q = net charge, t = time, then which of the following equations is correct?
questions.explanation: I = Q/t. The S.I unit of charge is coulomb, time is second, then current in units of coulomb per second is ' amper e '. Another formula for calculating current is I = V/R (derived by Ohm ’ s law), where I = current ﬂowing through the conductor, V = Voltage, and R = Resistance (at constant temperature).

questions.question: Whose law states that at a junction in an electric circuit, the sum of the currents ﬂowing into the junction is equal to the sum of the currents ﬂowing out of the junction?
questions.explanation: Gusta v Rober t Kir chhoff.Kirchhoff's ﬁrst law (Kirchhoff's junction rule). Kirchhoff's second law (Kirchhoff's loop rule) - The directed sum of the potential differences (voltages) around any closed loop is zero. Victor Franz Hess discovered cosmic rays.

questions.question: Wheatstone bridge is an arrangement of _________ resistors used for accurate measurement of resistance.
questions.explanation: four . A Wheatst one bridge cir cuit {invented by Samuel Hunter Christie (1833), popularized by Sir Charles Wheatstone (1843)} consists of four arms (two arms - known resistances, an unknown resistance and a variable resistance}. It works on the principle of null de ﬂ ection, i.e., when the Wheatstone bridge is balanced the ratio of their resistances are equal and no current ﬂows through the galvanometer.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding fuse wire?

options.a: It has a low melting point and low conductivity.
options.b: It has a high melting point and low conductivity
options.c: It has a low melting point and high conductivity.
options.d: It has a high melting point and high conductivity.

questions.explanation: The commonly used wire in the fuse is an alloy of tin (Sn) and lead (Pb). An electrical fuse is a circuit safety device to protect electrical systems.

questions.question: Why do atoms and nonpolar molecules have no dipole moment ?

options.a: Because their electronic charge cloud is missing
options.b: Because their electronic charge cloud is scattered
options.c: Because their electronic charge cloud is asymmetrically distributed
options.d: Because their electronic charge cloud is symmetrically distributed

questions.explanation: A dipole moment (vector quantity) is a measurement of the separation of two opposite electrical charges. Dipole moment (μ) = q r (q =× charge, r = distance between the charges). Dir ection is from negative charge to positive charge.

questions.question: What happens to the magnetic ﬁeld produced by a given current in the conductor when the distance increases?
questions.explanation: It decr eases. The magnitude of the magnetic ﬁeld produced at a given point incr eases as the current through the wire increases. Magnetic ﬁeld is the region around a moving charge that generates a ﬁeld. SI Unit of Magnetic Field Intensity - T esla (T) .

questions.question: The amount of work done in moving a charge of 4C across two points having a potential difference of 6V is ______ .
questions.explanation: 24 J. P otential diff er ence deﬁ ned as the work done to move unit electric charge from one point to another in an electric circuit. It is given by V = W/Q; i.e. W = V Q; W = 6 4 = 24 × × joules.

questions.question: What is the coil of wire in the electric room heater known as?
questions.explanation: Element . Nichr ome wir e is used as a heating element because it is very stable, even at high temperatures.

questions.question: In the symbol for the electric cell, the thicker, shorter line represents the:
questions.explanation: Negativ e terminal. The longer, thinner line represents the positive terminal. An electric cell is a device, which converts chemical energy into electrical energy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct ?

options.a: Magnetic ﬂux is a vector quantity.
options.b: Two magnetic ﬁeld lines may intersect.
options.c: The net magnetic ﬂux through any closed surface is zero.
options.d: Earth's magnetic poles coincide with the geographic poles.

questions.explanation: Magnetic ﬁeld lines are continuous loops, all closed surfaces have as many magnetic ﬁeld lines going in as coming out. Hence, the net magnetic ﬂux through a closed surface is zero.

questions.question: What is the total charge of an electric dipole?
questions.explanation: 0. An electric dipole is a pair of equal and opposite charges, therefore the total charge in an electric dipole will be z er o.

questions.question: Find the acceleration (in m/ ) of a 𝑠2 body which accelerates from 5 m/s to 10 m/s in 2 seconds.
questions.explanation: 2.5 m/sec2.The formula for acceleration is: a = ,(𝑣 − 𝑢) 𝑡 where: a = acceleration v =ﬁnal velocity u = initial velocity t = time taken Given values: Initial velocity (u) = 5 m/s Final velocity (v) = 10 m/s Time (t) = 2 seconds Putting these into the formula: a =(10 − 5) 2a =⇒a = 2.5 m/s².

questions.question: A javelin thrown by an athlete is in ________ motion.
questions.explanation: cur vilinear . This is because the javelin follows a curved trajectory due to the in ﬂ uence of gravity and the initial angle of release. Curvilinear motion refers to the motion of a particle along a curved path. Periodic motion: Motion repeating in regular intervals (Example - Rotation of the earth around the sun). Rectilinear motion: Motion in a straight line (Example - An object falling straight down). Q.84 . Identify the INCORRECT pair regarding motion and their examples? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (2nd Shift) (a) Translatory motion – A ball falling from the cliff (b) Periodic motion – Hands of a clock (c) Oscillatory motion – Earth moving around the sun (d) Rotatory motion – Blades of a fan Sol.84.(c) Oscillatory motion involves repeated back - and - forth movement around a ﬁx ed point, like a pendulum.Other examples : Oscillatory motion - Pendulum, swing, vibrating string. Periodic motion - Wave motion, planetary orbits. Rotatory motion - Merry-go- round, wheel rotation. Translatory motion - Car moving on a straight road, projectile motion.

questions.question: What happens when two forces act in the opposite directions on an object?

options.a: The net force acting on the object is the difference between the two objects.
options.b: The net force acting on the object is the difference between the two forces.
options.c: The net force acting on the object is the total of the two forces.
options.d: The net force acting on the object is the sum of the two objects.

questions.explanation: When two forces act in opposite directions on an object, the net force (or resultant force) is the difference between the magnitudes of the two forces. This is because the forces are opposing each other. For example, if a 5 N force acts to the right and a 3 N force acts to the left, the net force would be: Net force = 5 N - 3 N = 2 N (to the right).

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct relationship ?
questions.explanation: F = ma. Newton's second law is often stated as F = ma, which means the force (F) acting on an object is equal to the mass (m) of the object times its acceleration (a). This means the more mass an object has, the more force you need to accelerate it, and the greater the force, the greater the object's acceleration. SI unit of Force = Newtons (N).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT applicable to force ?

options.a: Force may increase the mass of the object
options.b: Force may change the direction of a moving object
options.c: Force may make an object move
options.d: Force may change the shape of an object

questions.explanation: Force can only change the speed, shape, and direction of the motion but is not able to change the mass. Force (F) : S.I unit – Newton (N) or kg m s-2. Force can make a body that is at rest tomove. It can stop a moving body or slow it down. It can accelerate the speed of a moving body.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of inertia at rest?

options.a: Falling down backward when a vehicle starts immediately
options.b: Falling down of dust particle while dusting a cloth
options.c: The detachment of leaves/fruits due to shaking
options.d: The sudden application of brakes in a vehicle

questions.explanation: The sudden application of br ak es in a v ehicle. Newton's First Law of Motion, also known as the law of inertia, states that an object will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force. Inertia is the body's resistance to changes in its state. Inertia of rest means a body at rest stays at rest until an external force acts on it. Inertia of motion means a body in motion continues moving until an external force stops it.

questions.question: Which of the following forces can only be applied when in contact with an object ?
questions.explanation: F rictional for ce is de ﬁ ned as the force produced between the two surfaces that oppose the motion when they come in contact with each other. Some examples: Walking, Writing, Skating, etc.

questions.question: A bus moving on a straight road at a speed of 10 km/h increases its speed to 70 km/h in 2 minutes. Find its average acceleration.
questions.explanation: 0.5 km/minute2.Given : Final velocity, v = 70 km/h = km/min. Initial7 6velocity, u = 10 km/h = km/min. Time1 6 period, t = 2 min. We know that, Average acceleration, a = =𝑣 − 𝑢 𝑡7 6 – 1 6 2 = = 0.5 km/min2.

questions.question: What is the metric unit of pressure that is equal to 0.986923 atm?
questions.explanation: Bar . The ‘atm’ is mostly used for measuring and describing atmospheric pressure. ‘bar’ is also used for atmospheric pressure but is also used to measure the pressure inside vessels. 1 bar = 0.986923 atm. 1 atm = 1.01325 bar. Other units: 1 Quart = 32 ﬂuid ounces or 4 cups, 1 Yard = 3 feet or 36 inches (0.9144 meters), 1 Gallon = 3.785 liters.

questions.question: By observing the motion of objects on an inclined plane __________ deduced that objects move with a constant speed when no force acts on them.
questions.explanation: Galileo. The law of inertia was inferred by Galileo from observations of motion of a ball on a double inclined plane. Galileo concluded that an object moving on a frictionless horizontal plane must neither have acceleration nor retardation, i.e. it should move with constant velocity.

questions.question: The measure of the force that can cause an object to rotate about an axis is called:
questions.explanation: T or que = Force × Distance, SI unit - newton-metre, Dimension - [M1L2 T-2]. Moment of inertia: The quantity expressed by the body resisting angular acceleration. I = L/⍵. where; I = inertia, L = angular momentum, ⍵= angular velocity. SI unit - kg⋅m2. Dimension - [M¹ L² T⁰].

questions.question: The forces exerted on a body during a short period are known as:
questions.explanation: Impulse. Surface tension - The property of the surface of a liquid that allows it to resist an external force, due to the cohesive nature of its molecules. Tensile stress - Capacity of a material to endure a pulling (tensile) force.

questions.question: Which law was developed in the 1600s to describe that any force applied to a con ﬁ ned ﬂuid is transmitted equally in all directions, regardless of the shapeof the container?
questions.explanation: P ascal’ s law. Gr aham ’ s law of diffusion : It describes the relationship between the rate of diffusion and the densities of gases .R1/R2= (M2/M1)1/2, where R 1, R 2are diffusion rates of gases 1 and 2, and M 1and M 2their respective molecular masses. The law is a simple consequence of kinetic theory.

questions.question: The suitability of post tensioning is good for :
questions.explanation: long spans. Post tensioning is a technique for reinforcing concrete, in which prestressing steel cables inside plastic ducts are positioned in the forms before the concrete is placed. Pr etensioning - The technique in which we are imparting tension in strands before placing the concrete. It is more durable and reliable.

questions.question: Select the option that is true regarding the following two statements labelled Assertion

options.a: and Reason (R). (A): An object slips less on a rough surface than a smooth surface. (R): When a surface is rough, frictional force increases. SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (1st shift) (a) Assertion (A) is true and Reason (R) is false.
options.b: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are the true but Reason (R) is not a correct explanation of Assertion (A).
options.c: Assertion (A) is false and Reason (R) is true.
options.d: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are the true and Reason (R) is a correct explanation of Assertion (A).

questions.explanation: F rictional for ce is the resistance encountered when two surfaces slide or attempt to slide against each other, resulting from the interaction between their roughness and molecular forces. Formula - F (friction force) = μ (coe ﬃ cient of friction) N (normal × force). Normal F or ce - The force that surfaces exert to prevent solid objects from passing through each other.

questions.question: The given equation provides the property of the motion of an object, traversing a circular path. What is 'v' in this equation ? (a c= v²/R)
questions.explanation: Speed. Centripetal acceler ation - That is directed towards the center of the circle. It is caused by the change in direction of the velocity vector as the object moves around the circle. Centripetal Acceleration (ac) formula: ac= v2/r (where v is the speed, r is the radius). Dimensional formula of centripetal acceleration = [ M0L1T-2].

questions.question: What is another name for center - seeking force ?
questions.explanation: Centripetal. Examples of Centripetal Force - Loop of Roller Coaster, Orbiting Planets. V an der W aals for ces - Weak intermolecular forces of attraction between molecules, arising from temporary ﬂuctuations in electron density.

questions.question: Newton's ﬁrst law of motion is also known as ______.
questions.explanation: Law of Iner tia. Newt on ' s ﬁ rst law of motion - A body remains in the state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line unless and until an external force acts on it.

questions.question: Which type of friction is considered as a self - adjusting force?
questions.explanation: Static F riction - Force that keeps an object at rest. Kinetic F riction - It is a force that acts between moving surfaces. Centripetal F riction - The frictional force supplies the centripetal force and is numerically equal to it.

questions.question: The force exerted by a charged body on another charged or uncharged body is known as ______ .
questions.explanation: Electr ostatic for ce - This force between two charged particles is directly proportional to the product of the charges and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the particles. The same charge on two particles - the force will be repulsive and the opposite charge on the particles - the force will be attractive.

questions.question: The substances which reduce friction are called ________.
questions.explanation: L ubricants - Any substance that is physically integrated for the purpose of reducing friction between two or more moving surfaces. Examples - Grease and oil.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding air pressure?

options.a: High pressure is associated with cloudy skies and wet weather
options.b: Low pressure is associated with clear and sunny skies.
options.c: The air always moves from high pressure areas to low pressure areas.
options.d: The air pressure is lowest at sea level and increases with height.

questions.explanation: Air pressure is de ﬁ ned as the pressure exerted by the weight of air on the earth’s surface. When there is a larger pressure difference between the pressure zones, the wind travels quicker and it travels from an area of high pressure to low pressure.

questions.question: A ball possesses 3000 units of momentum. What would be the ball's new momentum if its velocity was doubled?
questions.explanation: 6000 units. We know that Momentum is directly proportional to the object's mass (m) and velocity (v). Momentum (p) = mass (m) v elocity (v). × And if velocity is doubled, momentum is also doubled. Hence momentum = 2 3000 = 6000 units.×

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an application of the third law of motion ?

options.a: A ﬁelder pulls his hands gradually with the moving ball while holding a catch.
options.b: Colliding with a player while kicking a football and feeling hurt.
options.c: As the sailor jumps in the forward direction, the boat moves backward .
options.d: A forward force on the bullet and recoil of the gun.

questions.explanation: Newton’s third law of Motion - States that to every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Force : Thepush or pull on an object with mass causes it to change its velocity. SI unit of Force - Newton. Dimension of Force - [ML T-2]. CGS unit of Force - dyne.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct order of friction ?
questions.explanation: Static > Sliding > Rolling. Static F riction : A force that hinders the movement of an object moving along the path. Sliding F riction : Resistance created by any two objects when sliding against each other. Rolling F riction : The force resisting the motion of a rolling body on a surface.

questions.question: Identify the correct statement about inertia.

options.a: Greater the mass, greater the inertia.
options.b: Lesser the weight, greater the inertia
options.c: Lesser the mass, greater the inertia

questions.explanation: Gr eater the mass, gr eater the iner tia. As inertia is directly proportional to the mass of the object (I = mr2)so Inertia will increase if mass increases. Inertia is de ﬁ ned as a property of matter by which it tries to maintain its state of rest or of uniform motion along a straight line. Types of Inertia include Inertia of Rest, Inertia of Motion and Inertia of direction.

questions.question: Motion of an object is ______ if its velocity is constant.
questions.explanation: Uniform motion - When an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time, then its motion is called uniform motion. Example - Motion of the blades of a ceiling fan. Non-uniform motion - Objects move with different speeds and do not cover equal distances in equal intervals of time. Example - Speed of train.

questions.question: ________time graph shows speed of an object.
questions.explanation: Distance. In this graph, the slope of the line is equal to the speed of the object. Speed and distance are scalarquantities. V elocity (Displacement-time graph, vector quantity). Acceler ation (velocity - time graph, vector quantity), Displacement (vector quantity).

questions.question: Which physical theory explains the generation of thrust by rocket engines, jet engines and de ﬂ ating balloons?
questions.explanation: Newt on ’ s laws of motion. Third Law is often given as an explanation for the generation of thrust (to every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction).

questions.question: The range of ______ force is of the order of 10−16m.
questions.explanation: W eak Nuclear F or ce - Very Short 10-16m, (Range), 10-13(Relative Strength). Gravitational Force - In ﬁ nite (Range), 10-39(Relative Strength), Electromagnetic Force - In ﬁ nite (Range), 10-2(Relative strength), Strong Nuclear Force - Short Nuclear size 10-15m (Range), 1(Relative Strength).

questions.question: Acceleration is equal to the rate of change of ______.
questions.explanation: V elocity . Acceler ation is de ﬁ ned as the rate at which an object changes its velocity. It is a vector quantity. Unit of acceleration is the metre per square second ( ).

questions.question: If two forces act on an object from opposite directions, then the magnitude of the net force acting on it is the ______ of the magnitudes of the two forces.
questions.explanation: Diff er ence. Net for ce is the sum total of all the forces which are acting on the body. Forces applied on an object in the same direction add to one another.

questions.question: With what do you divide thrust in a liquid to obtain the value of pressure?
questions.explanation: Ar ea. Thrust acting per unit area is known as pressure i.e. Pressure = Thrust/Area.

questions.question: How long will a sound wave take to travel 1.5 km, which has a frequency of 5 kHz and wavelength of 6 cm?
questions.explanation: 5 seconds. Given that, Frequency (f) = 5 kHz = 5000 Hz. Wavelength (λ) = 6 cm = 0.06 m. Distance = 1.5 km = 1500 m. The speed (v) of a wave is given by: 𝑣= frequency × wavelength 𝑣= 5000 Hz × 0.06 m = 300m/s. The distance to be traveled is 1.5 km = 1500 m. Time = =𝐷𝑖𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑛𝑐𝑒 𝑆𝑝𝑒𝑒𝑑1500 𝑚 300𝑚/𝑠 = 5 seconds.

questions.question: Which wave oscillates parallel to the motion of the sound wave?
questions.explanation: Longitudinal wa v e : In this, the oscillations occur parallel to the direction of the wave's motion. Transverse wave : In this, the oscillations occur perpendicular to the direction of the wave's motion. Examples include water waves and waves on a string. Mechanical wave : These waves require a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel through.

questions.question: Among the given options, which one causes an echo?

options.a: When sound is re ﬂ ected
options.b: When sound waves travel through a solid medium
options.c: When sound waves travel through a liquid medium
options.d: When sound waves travel through a vacuum

questions.explanation: When sound is r e ﬂ ected. E cho : The sound is heard more than once because of the time difference between the initial production of the sound waves and their return from the reﬂ ecting surface. A pplications of echo - Measuring Depth and Height, Measuring Distance, Medical Diagnosis.Q.119. Among the following, in which material the speed of sound is highest? (at 25°C) SSC CHSL 16/03/2023 (1st Shift) (a) Nickel (b) Steel (c) Iron (d) Aluminium Sol.119.(d) Aluminium. Speed of sound (meters/second) in different media at 25 ºC: Aluminium (6420 m/s), Nickel (6040 m/s), Steel (5960 m/s), Iron (5950 m/s), Brass (4700 m/s).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding sound?

options.b: In human beings, the vibration of vocal cords produce sound.

questions.explanation: Sound is a mechanical wave and needs a material medium like air, water, steel etc. for its propagation. It cannot travel through vacuum. Audio Frequency spectrum of the human ear is to be between 20 Hertz and 20,000 Hertz. Speed of sound in different mediums: Water (Sea) - 1531 m/s, Water (distilled) - 1498 m/s, Air - 346 m/s.

questions.question: Loudness of sound is proportional to the _____ of the amplitude of the vibration producing the sound.
questions.explanation: Squar e. The loudness of sound is expressed in the units called the Decibel. The symbol of the decibel is dB. The sound pressure level of audible sound ranges from 0 dB through 120 dB.

questions.question: What is the study of the production and propagation of sound waves called?
questions.explanation: Acoustics . Optics is the branch of physical science that deals with the properties and phenomena of both visible and invisible light. Phot onics is the study of light and other types of radiant energy whose quantum unit is the photon. Astr ophysics is a branch of space science that applies the laws of physics and chemistry to seek to understand the universe.

questions.question: If an object executes 10 oscillations per second, then its frequency in kilohertz is equal to :
questions.explanation: 1 kilohertz = 1000 oscillation per second. 10 oscillation per second = = 0.01 kilohertz.

questions.question: The sound of thunder is heard much later than the ﬂash of light is visible. What does it represent?

options.a: The speed of sound is much less than the speed of light.
options.b: The speed of sound is three times the speed of light.
options.c: The speed of sound is twice the speed of light.
options.d: The speed of sound is equal to the speed of light.

questions.explanation: The speed of sound in air is about 346 meters per second. Light travels at a speed of 300,000 km/s (186,000 mi/s) from a stationary source. Time taken by Light - Moon to Earth: 1.3 seconds and Sun to Earth (1 AU) : 8.3 minutes.

questions.question: Two masses of 1 kg and 2 kg were dropped from a height of 3.2 metres. Their respective velocities just before touching the ground will be: (Assume acceleration due to gravity g = 10 m/s2)
questions.explanation: 8 m/s for both. We can calculate the velocities of the two masses just before touching the ground using the equation of motion for free fall: 𝑣=2𝑔ℎWhere: v = velocity just before touching the ground g = acceleration due to gravity (10 m/s2) h = height from which the masses were dropped (3.2m) For both masses (1 kg and 2 kg), the velocity will be the same because the equation is independent of mass: v= 2✕10✕3. 2 𝑣=64 𝑣= 8 m/s Hence, the velocities of both masses just before touching the ground will be 8 m/s.

questions.question: Identify the INCORRECT statement for the universal law of gravitation.

options.a: It is the force that binds us to earth
options.b: It is the force causing tides due to the stars and earth.
options.c: It is the force that keeps motion of planets around the Sun.
options.d: It is the force that assists motion of the moon around earth.

questions.explanation: Newton's law of universal gravitation - Any particle of matter in the universe attracts another one with a force varying directly as the product of the masses and inversely as the square of the distance between them. G’ is denoted as the gravitational constant. Value of G = 6.67×10-11Nm2/kg2. Tides are caused by the combined gravitation attraction of the Sun and Moon on the Earth.

questions.question: Identify the correct statement about gravity.

options.a: The unit of g is the same as that of acceleration
options.b: The unit of g is the same as that of velocity
options.c: The unit of g is the same as that of mass.
options.d: The unit of g is the same as that of friction.

questions.explanation: Gravity : The universal force of attraction acting between all matter in the Universe. Anything that has mass, also has gravity. Isaac Newton discovered the laws of gravity and motion. The value of the acceleration due to the gravity on earth is 9.8 m/s2. The SI unit of gravity is the newton (N).

questions.question: Which of the following laws represented by the formula T2∝R3, compares the orbital period and radius of the orbit of a planet with that of other planets ?
questions.explanation: K epler ' s Thir d Law : The square of the period of revolution of any planet is directly proportional to the third power of the semi-major axis of the elliptical orbit of that planet. Br agg' s Law : 2dsin(θ) = nλ, where, d (distance between crystal lattice planes), θ (Angle of incidence), n (Integer), λ is the wavelength of the X-rays. Copernicus’ s Law : Proposed a heliocentric system, that the planets orbit around the Sun.

questions.question: Who among the following was the ﬁrst to conclude that in vacuum all objects fall with the same acceleration g and reach the ground at the same time?
questions.explanation: Galileo Galilei (father of observational astronomy, modern physics and the scienti ﬁ c method). He is known for observations of the Moon, phases of Venus, moons around Jupiter, sunspots.

questions.question: Which instrument was used to detect gravitational waves for the very ﬁrst time?
questions.explanation: LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory) is a large-scale physics experiment and observatory to detect cosmic gravitational waves and to develop gravitational - wave observations as an astronomical tool.

questions.question: Who was the ﬁrst to use the term 'horsepower' that refers to the power produced by an engine ?
questions.explanation: James W att was a Scottish engineer and inventor. Watt de ﬁ ned one horsepower as the power required to lift 33,000 pounds by one foot in one minute, which is equivalent to about 746 watts. Albert Einstein was a physicist who is best known for his theory of relativity and the famous equation E = mc2.

questions.question: If an object of mass 2 kg is dropped from a height of 10 metres, what will be the ratio of its potential energy and kinetic energy at the height of 5 metres (g = 10 m/sec2)
questions.explanation: 1 : 1. When the object is dropped from a height of 10 meters, its potential energy (PE) is converted to kinetic energy (KE) as it falls. At the height of 5 meters, the object has lost half of its initial potential energy and has gained an equal amount of kinetic energy. Initial Potential energy (PE) = mgh = 2 kg × 10 m/s² × 10 m = 200 J At 5 meters, Potential energy (PE) = mgh = 2 kg × 10 m/s² × 5 m = 100 J Kinetic energy (KE) = Initial PE - PE = 200 J - 100 J = 100 JRatio of PE to KE = 100 J : 100 J = 1:1

questions.question: What kind of energy does a yo-yo have before it is released?
questions.explanation: P otential ener gy . The energy possessed by a body due to its position and con ﬁ guration is called potential energy. Potential energy = mgh (where m = mass of an object, g = acceleration due to gravity, and h = height).

questions.question: Match list I and list II.List I List II a) Potential energy i) Solar thermal b) Chemical energy ii) Wind turbine c) Kinetic energy iii) Hydropower plant d) Radiation energy iv) Diesel generator
questions.explanation: (a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i). Potential energy - The stored energy in any object or system by virtue of its position or arrangement of parts. In air (3 × 108m/s), in water (2.26 × 108m/s), in glass (2 × 108 m/s), in diamond (1.25 ×108m/s). Light radiation travels at a speed of approximately 299,792,458 (m/s) or 3 × 108m/s in a vacuum.

questions.question: A ____ is one billionth of a metre.
questions.explanation: nanometr e. In the International System of Units, the preﬁ x "nano" means one-billionth, or 10-9. Special length units for short and large lengths are: 1 micrometre (µm) = 10–6m; 1 fermi (f) = 10–15m; 1 angstrom ( Å) = 10–10m; 1 astronomical unit (AU) (average distance of the Sun from the Earth) = 1.496 × 1011m.

questions.explanation: 303. 0˚Celsius = 273.15°Kelvin, So 30˚Celsius = (273.15°+ 30˚) Kelvin = 303.15 Kelvin ≅ 303 K elvin.

questions.question: Who propounded the famous equation E = mc2in 1905?
questions.explanation: Alber t Einstein gave thefamous mass - energy equivalence relation. This equation (E = mc2) is part of his theory of Special Relativity and states that energy (E) is equal to mass (m) multiplied by the square of the speed of light (c). It illustrates the profound relationship between matter and energy, showing that mass can be converted into energy and vice versa.

questions.question: What was the name of the wind measuring instrument invented for the ﬁrst time in 1450?

questions.explanation: Cy clotr on. It is a device invented by E.O. Lawrence in 1929, that is used for accelerating charged particles (such as protons, deutron or α–particles) to high velocities.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct formula for moment of inertia?
questions.explanation: I = mr2.Where; I = moment of inertia, m = point mass, r = axis of rotation. Moment of iner tia - It is a measure of an object's resistance to changes in its rotation rate. It is a property that depends on both the mass distribution of the object and the axis of rotation. The moment of inertia is analogous to mass in linear motion i.e the larger the moment of inertia, the more torque is required to produce a given angular acceleration. Unit - kg·m², Dimension - [M L2T0].

questions.question: The given equation describes the _________ relation. s = u t +1/2 a 𝑡2

There are three equations of motion (given by Issac Newton) that can be used to derive components such as displacement(s), velocity (initial and ﬁnal), time(t), and acceleration(a). They are First: v = u + at (velocity-time), Second: s = ut + ½ at² (position-time), Third: v2= u2+ 2as (position-velocity).

questions.question: Identify an application in which solar cells are not used.
questions.explanation: Lift system. A solar cell(photovoltaic cell) is an electronic device that converts the energy of light directly into electricity by the photovoltaic effect. Radio is the technology of signaling and communicating using radio waves (frequency between 3 Hz and 3,000 GHz).

questions.question: Air _____ on heating and ________ on cooling.
questions.explanation: Expands, contr acts. Heating air causes the air molecules to gain thermal energy, move faster, and spread out, resulting in the expansion of air and a decrease in air density. Cooling air causes the air molecules to lose thermal energy, slow down, and come closer together, leading to the contraction of air and an increase in air density
